prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This setup is identical to what we used in the cycle-0 project. Given the line-width (400 km/s), we will bin the data into dv= 28 km/s bins.

The source has a distance of 84 Mpc (1"=407 pc). The requested resolution is 0.04", correspond to a liner scale of 16 pc, sufficient to resolve GMCs and the torus around a putative AGN. Combining our cycle-0 obs, which has a relution of 0.25" and LAS of 3", the new obs will enable a good fedility map over the central kpc of the source down to 16 pc.

For the CO(6-5) line, the observed flux is f_CO(6-5)=1006 Jy km/s. Assuming all of this is in central 1", the mean surface density is 1006/400*28/1*0.04^2 = 0.11 Jy/beam=110 mJy/beam (line with =400 km/s, bandwidth=28 km/s). The RMS of designed obs is 10 mJy/beam over 28 km/s. So the line should be deteted with S/N=11.
Justification for bandwidth: The line width (398 km/s) is taken from single dish onservations that did not resolve the source. Our cycle-0 observations indicate line width of 60 -- 100 km/s at individual pointings. The chosen bandwidth should be suffient to resolve the lines in individual pointings.
This setup should sufficiently resolve the line and cover the whole line profile.
This obs is to complement the SG (C36-7 B7 12CO), providing the short baselines in order to cover the entire emission region of 2.00 arsec.

In this SG, we want to detect both CO(3-2) and HCO+(4-3) lines. The single dish data for the CO SLED collected by Xu et al. 2015 indicate a CO(3-2)/CO(6-5) flux ratio of 0.5. Given the observed CO(6-5) flux f_CO(6-5)=1006 Jy km/s, the mean CO(3-2) surface density in the central 1" (400 pc) is 1006*0.5/400*28/1*0.15^2 = 0.8 Jy/beam=800 mJy/beam (line with =400 km/s, bandwidth=28 km/s). The RMS of designed obs is 13 mJy/beam. So the CO (3-2) line should be deteted with S/N=60.
The SMA observations of NGC4418 (Sakamoto et al. 2014). also a LIRG with an AGN, found a flux ratio between HCO+(4-3) and CO(3-2) of 0.16. Therefore the mean surface density of the HCO+ line emission is 800*0.16=130 mJy/beam. This will be detected with S/N=10.
Justification for the bandwidth: The line width (398 km/s) is from single dish data which did not resolve the disk. Our cycle-0 observations indicate line width of 60 -- 100 km/s at individual pointings. The chosen bandwidth should be sufficient to resolve the lines in individual pointings.
This setup should sufficiently resolve the line and cover the whole line profile.
This obs take advantage of the highest resolution that ALMA offers. Together with SG(C36-5 B7 12CO, HCO+), the two observations probe the angular scales from 0.04" to 2".

In this SG, we want to detect both CO(3-2) and HCO+(4-3) lines. The single dish data for CO SLED collected by Xu et al. (2015) indicate a CO(3-2)/CO(6-5) flux ratio of 0.5. Given the observed CO(6-5) flux f_CO(6-5)=1006 Jy km/s, the mean CO(3-2) surface density in the central 1" (400 pc) is 1006*0.5/400*28/1*0.04^2 = 0.056 Jy/beam=56 mJy/beam (line with =400 km/s, bandwidth=28 km/s). The RMS of designed obs is 0.93 mJy/beam. So the CO (3-2) line should be deteted with S/N=60.
The SMA observations of NGC4418 (Sakamoto et al. 2014), also a LIRG with an AGN, found a flux ratio between HCO+(4-3) and CO(3-2) of 0.16. Therefore the mean surface density of the HCO+ line emission is 56*0.16=9.3 mJy/beam. This will be detected with S/N=10.
Justification for bandwidth: see that in SG(36-5 B7 12CO, HCO+).
This setup should sufficiently resolve the line and cover the whole line profile.
The resolution matches that of CO(3-2) observation in SG(C36-7 B7 12CO, HCO+). The HCN line is assumed to be concentrated in the inner 0.4".

The SMA obervations of NGC4418 (Sakamoto et al. 201$) found a HCN(4-3) to CO(3-2) flux ratio of 0.33. Assuming this applies to NGC34, and given the mean surface brightness of CO(3-2) 56 mJy/beam (estimated in SG(C36-7 B7 12CO, HCO+)),the mean HCN surface density is 56 *0.33 = 18 mJy/beam. The RMS of designed obs is 1.8 mJy/beam. So the HCN line should be deteted with S/N=10.
Justification of bandwidth: see that in SG(C36-7 B7 12CO, HCO+).
This setup should sufficiently resolve the line and cover the whole line profile.
This obs is matched to SG(C36-5 B7 12CO), in order to provide information on CO isotope to constrain the CO optical depth.

Assuming a 13CO(3-2)/CO(3-2) flux ratio of 0.1, and given the mean CO(3-2) surface brightness of 800 mJy/beam (estimated in SG(C36-5 B7 12CO, HCO+)), the mean 13CO(3-2) surface density is 800 * 0.1 = 80 mJy/beam. The RMS of designed obs is 8 mJy/beam. So the 13CO (3-2) line should be deteted with S/N=10.
Justificantion for bandwidth: same bandwidth is assumed here as that for 12CO(3-2) observations.
This setup should sufficiently resolve the line and cover the whole line profile.
The resolution and LAS are so chosen as that the emission feature in Fig.4 is fully resolved and covered.

In this SG we want to detect the diffuse emission featuer found in our Cycle-0 Band 9 map (Fig.4 in science case). The feature has a mean surface brightness of 1.8 Jy/beam, with a beam size of 0".25 and bandwidth 200 km/s. Assuming the feauter is a CO outflow and having a CO(4-3)/CO(6-5) flux ratio of 0.65, the predicted surface brightness of the CO(4-3) emission of the feature is 1.8*0.65*(22/200)*(0.16/0.25)^2=0.053 Jy/beam =53 mJy/beam. The RMS of designed obs is 5.3 mJy/beam. So the the feature should be deteted with S/N=10.
Justification of bandwidth: the average velocity dispersion is about 60 - 100 km/s. The chosen bandwidth should be sufficient to resolve the line profile at individual pointings.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to make high resolution ALMA maps (~0".04, corresponding to a linear scale of ~16 pc) of CO(6-5), CO(4-3), CO(3-2), 13CO(3-2), HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3) line emissions and of the continuum at 435, 650, and 870 um in the nuclear region of NGC 34. NGC 34, a nearby luminous IR galaxy (LIRG) with a Sy2 nucleus and a nuclear starburst (SB), represents a class of final stage mergers that are undergoing SB, AGN, outflows, and other extreme phenomena simultaneously just before transforming into ellipticals. The proposed observations will disentangle these complex processes and probe the relations among them. We aim to answering the following questions: Is the SB occurring in a separated nucleus or in a circum-nuclear disk around the AGN? What are the physical conditions of the SB associated gas and the gas in the AGN torus? What is the SFE (= SFR/M_gas) and how is Sigma_SFR related to Sigma_gas? Is there any dense gas outflow and what powers it? How is the gas reacting to the AGN and SB feedbacks? With a favorite sky location for ALMA observations (Dec=-12 deg) and a close distance (84 Mpc, 1" = 400 pc), NGC~34 is an ideal target for high spatial resolution ALMA observations.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
